Make sure you use SARGable predicate in WHERE clauses and JOINS to prevent additional costs on CPU
Prefer using INNER JOINS instead of NATURAL JOINS for better performance
While using ORDER BY in queries prefer using Column names instead of indexes for better maintainability and readability of queries in code
Try to separate JOIN and WHERE clauses by following ANSI-Standard joins format to improve maintainability and readabitliy
Prefer not using GROUP BY clauses in queries as it hampers the performance and is inefficient
Make sure the identifiers defined in SQL are not quoted <""> as it is confusing to read and reduces maintainability of code
To ensure query performance make sure you do not use Dynamic SQL, specially for modules that are called too often
When inserting data into columns always define column names to prevent mistakes and wrong updates
Always use MINUS or EXCEPT operator instead of NOT EXISTS and NOT IN subqueries for better execution performance
Ensure that you are not making queries and Joins on too many tables or views as it hampers execution performance
When using EXISTS or NOT EXISTS clauses make sure that you refer to parent object and not  independent clauses to ensure better performance
Prefer replacing DISTINCT in your queries with a WHERE, FROM clause that fetches only the required data
To improve the readability of your SQL statements use IN test condition instead of multiple OR conditions on same identifier
Ensure to handle exception in a catch block and not leave it empty
Ensure to use WHEN OTHERS with WHEN for exception handling to prevent unexpected behavior
Ensure to propagate errors to client instead of using with NULL when handling exceptions through WHEN OTHERS
Prefer to use a similar syntax for JOIN in same SQL queries and not mix ANSI and non-ANSI syntax
When using LIKE operator make sure the first character in search string is not a wildcard character as it reduces execution performance
Ensure that when using triangular joins you restrict the results with some extra conditions to avoid severe performance issues
Make sure you don't have synonyms with both private and public definitions to avoid complexity, try renaming one of them instead
Always use 'IS NULL' or 'IS NOT NULL' to check for Nullability instead of using '=' or '!=' operators
Improve the readability and maintainability of your queries by using aliases for tables
Ensure column references in queries are qualified to avoid any ambiguous and undefined references
Ensure that when creating synonyms you define them as PRIVATE and not PUBLIC
When creating synonyms ensure that you do not reference a missing object as it will create errors at execution
Ensure that when chaining synonyms you do not loop them leading to synonym referring to itself as it will cause a error during execution
Ensure using a set-oriented approach instead of using a iterative approach caused by using cursors inside loops for better performance of queries
Ensure to use VARCHAR2 or NVARCHAR2 instead of CHAR, VARCHAR or NCHAR as the latter will be deprecated and uses more disk space
Ensure that you use CLOB, NCLOB or BLOB datatypes in tables instead of LONG or LONG RAW as the latter are deprecated
Each table should have a clustered index
Errors should be handled in stored procedures and functions
Stored Procedures should always RETURN a status value. RETURN 0 to indicate success and any non-zero value indicates failure.
Avoid Artifacts with a Complex SELECT Clause (SQL)
LIKE conditions should not be used without wildcards characters
XXL Tables should have a primary key / unique key constraint / unique index
Tables should have a primary key / unique key constraint / unique index
Ensure to not use explain() method in production code so that performance is not reduced
Avoid having multiple Artifacts updating data on the same NoSQL Collection (JEE)
Avoid having multiple Artifacts inserting data on the same NoSQL Collection (JEE)
Avoid having multiple artifacts deleting data on the same NoSQL collections (JEE)
